docs.title: The CU Ecosystem for Gothenberg
docs.text: The CU Ecosystem consists of three elements: Accesscity, Pixity and the Swedish city of Gothenberg.

docs.title: Gothenberg
docs.text: The city is essentially the end point for the user, meaning that the whole idea of the CU Ecosystem is to get people out and about, visiting real events, exploring landmarks and engaging socially in Gothenberg.

docs.title: Accesscity
docs.text: The way they make their way around the city is by using Accesscity - a mobile app that leaverages AI technology combined with innovative navigation algorithms to make navigation in the city easy and accessible for all.

docs.title: Pixity
docs.text: However, users still need a reason to engage with the CU Ecosystem to begin with. This is where Pixity comes in - a separate solution that enhances Accesscity. Pixity combines board and digital game elements together with gamification design principles to provide an engaging way for people to create their journey through Gothenberg and motivate them to go out an explore using Accesscity to do so.

docs.title: The full ecosystem
docs.text: Put simply, users engage with Pixity first as it provides a playful way to get started with exploring with Accesscity. Once they are hooked, they can use Accesscity to actually navigate in an accessible way. This ultimately leads them to visiting real events, landmarks and social experiences in Gothenberg.

docs.title: Game overview
docs.text: This is intended as a cohesive paragraph or two that lets someone understand what you are working on. Include the below elements.

docs.title: 🕹️ Purpose of the game
docs.text: What is the primary purpose of the game outside of playing it? A serious game requires a serious goal like achieving a pedagogical objective, training goal, or intended social impact. If it is addressing a problem, explain what that problem is (for example, students have a hard time...)

docs.title: 🕹️ Intended use
docs.text: How does your game help achieve that serious goal? For example, how it is to be inserted into a pedagogical scenario or how will it be used in training, therapy, rehabilitation, etc. You should distinguish between a game that is stand alone, a supplement to another activity, etc.

docs.title: 🕹️ Justification for the use
docs.text: Is there research that shows that this is apt to be successful? Are there are other games or applications that take a similar approach? If this is an experiment to see if it will work, why does the researcher believe that it might? Essentially, why would we try this solution for the problem?

docs.title: 🕹️ Target audience
docs.text: Your target audience must be well defined. There’s a significant difference in a game teaching biology to a kindergartener or to a college student.

docs.title: 🕹️ Genre(s)
docs.text: The genre (or multiple genres) of your game.

docs.title: Gameplay
docs.text: This section would tell a player what to expect. Not a lot of detail (that comes later).

docs.title: 🕹️ Objectives
docs.text: What are the objectives of the game? Is it to reach a destination, retrieve the chalice, accrue the most money, or solve a puzzle in the fastest amount of time?

docs.title: 🕹️ Game Progression and Play Flow
docs.text: How does the game flow for the game player? Is there an overall scoring and objective for the game or is it a progression of levels? Is it endless? Is it based around a single playthrough? What does that playthrough look like?

docs.title: 🕹️ Mission, challenge, puzzle, etc. structure
docs.text: What are the different "beats" of the game defined? Does the player have a mission? Do they solve puzzles? Do they fight monsters? etc.

docs.title: Mechanics
docs.text: These are topics that should be covered if relevant. All games are different and not everything applies. Consider this a checklist to help you capture all that is important. It should be complete enough that someone could build a clone of your game based on this detail.

docs.title: 🕹️ Rules
docs.text: Include both implicit and explicit rules that define the interactions with your game.

docs.title: 🕹️ Model of the game universe
docs.text: Think of it as a simulation of a world, how do all the pieces interact? If it is a puzzle game, there may be no universe to discuss, but there is the layout and the structure of the puzzle. Included in the universe are: - Physics: How does the physical universe in your game work? If there are no physics, do not try to create them. - Economy: What is the economy of the game? How does it work? The economy incudes the items that the player is trying to collect as well as a world economy. How does a player earn or lose these items? - Other aspects: Other relevant aspects to the overall universe of the game.

docs.title: 🕹️ Character actions
docs.text: The different actions that the character can perform, such as movement, interaction with objects, combat with enemies, dialog choices, etc.

docs.title: 🕹️ Screen Flow
docs.text: How each screen is related to every other and a description of the purpose of each screen.

docs.title: Story and Narratives
docs.text: If you have a puzzle game, there is probably no backstory or story. As soon as you add an avatar of any sort, you have a story. It may be as simple as who the character is.

docs.title: 🕹️ Backstory
docs.text: If there is no plot or narrative in the story but you need to understand the background, that is a backstory. The backstory can also be setting the stage for the story that is going to unfold.

docs.title: 🕹️ Plot elements
docs.text: There are multiple patterns of a plot: the 3-act play, the hero’s journey, episodic, … Use one of the models to describe the story of the game.

docs.title: 🕹️ Game story progression
docs.text: Explain how the progression of the plot is exposed to the player. Remember that there are different approaches to the narrative: how it is exposed, who is telling it and the sequence that things happen. If you are using cut scenes to progress the story, describe the cut scenes in detail.

docs.title: Game World
docs.text: Describe the general look and feel of world. Of particular importance is whether the world is broken up into different areas that are relevant to the game. If it is, describe how they are connected, how the player moves between them, and how they relate to levels.

docs.title: 🕹️ Player avatar
docs.text: Indicate if the user has the ability to define their own avatar and what options they are able to define.

docs.title: 🕹️ Non-playable characters (NPCs)
docs.text: Identify the characters present, but not playable. Describe their backstory, personality, appearance and abilities. If there are characters that are relevant to the game but never seen, be sure to include them. Include enemies and opponents.

docs.title: Levels / Quests
docs.text: Provide a general description of how levels are used in the game as well as what their structure is. Identify different elements of each level, giving a synopsis of what its quest is, what is to be achieved in the level, how the player progresses through it, what they learn from it and what the ultimate end goal is.

docs.title: User Interface
docs.text: Describe all elements that interface the game and the players. For example, how is the game controlled, how does it look (art style), how does it sound (audio and music), etc.

docs.title: Pixity
docs.text: Pixity is a serious game solution that implements the design methodology of Gamification. It consists of two parts - a board game and digital quests. The users (in this case players) play a board game that allows them to build their path through Gothenberg in an interactive way. This path ends up at a final destination, for example a Gothenberg landmark, cafe or event hall. Then the user is urged to continue their quest by actually visiting the location, where they can scan a QR code allowing them to play a digital quest that takes place in that location and allows them to learn more about it, interact socially and generally spend time at the location.

docs.title: Primary goals
docs.text: Pixity has a few primary goals - providing a playful entry point to the ecosystem, creating a path through the city in an engaging and fun way, motivating users to use Accesscity to get to a destination in Gothenberg and helping them learn and interact with the location once they are there.

docs.title: 🕹️ Playful entry point
docs.text: Everyone is familiar with board games to some degree and most people enjoy them. Thus, Pixity is an inticing entry point for a task that otherwise might seem daunting or that users would not have any intrinsic motivation to perform. In this case, exploring a city and building their path through it.

docs.title: 🗺️ Creating a path through the city
docs.text: Using the engaging and fun aspects of games we can help users create a path unique to them. They can build their own narratives and end up at places that they may otherwise not have considered. This can all happen in a natural way that doesn't feel arbitrary, while they have fun.

docs.title: 🚌 Motivating users to use Accesscity
docs.text: By integrating Pixity with Accesscity, once the players have completed building their path through Gothenberg, they can reach their destination by using Accesscity. In this way Pixity can leverage gamification's ability to motivate in a more meta sense, by motivating players to engage with the ecosystem itself.

docs.title: 📱 Digital quests
docs.text:
By doing a digital quest in a certain location, Pixity can serve as a serious game that allows people to learn, explore and engage with the space around them. Maybe there is a quiz that asks them to observe their environment? Maybe there is a reward that they can obtain by getting a coffee? Maybe some other way to engage with their space in a social way? The possibilities are endless and Pixity can serve as a great external motivator for this.

Additionally, if these quests exist inside the Accesscity app itself, it is one more reason to get people to use it, once again allowing Pixity to be motivational in a meta sense.

docs.title: Design
docs.text: As mentioned, Pixity consists of a board game and a digital game. The full design blueprint and details for each can be found in the the Board game design document and Digital game design document
